text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] be a space with an inner product, and let [mathjaxinline]v\in V[/mathjaxinline] be a non-zero vector. Define [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] to be the set of all vectors [mathjaxinline]w\in V[/mathjaxinline] with the property that [mathjaxinline]\langle v,w\rangle = 0[/mathjaxinline].
True or false: [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is a subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline]. Prove your answer, or come up with a counterexample showing that it is not.

optioninput.options: ('I have proven it','I found a counterexample')

font.p: [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is in fact a subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline]. We can check the three criteria:

tr.td: [mathjax]\langle v, w_1 + w_2 \rangle = \langle v, w_1 \rangle + \langle v, w_2 \rangle = 0 + 0 = 0,[/mathjax]

font.p: so [mathjaxinline]w_1 + w_2 \in W[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is closed under addition.
If [mathjaxinline]w\in W[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a[/mathjaxinline] is a scalar, then

tr.td: [mathjax]\langle v, aw\rangle = a\langle v, w \rangle = a0 = 0,[/mathjax]

font.p: so [mathjaxinline]aw \in W[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is closed under scalar multiplication.
